articles.headline: Capitol Leaders Agree to a Deal on the Budget
articles.snippet: The deal, while modest in scope, amounts to a cease-fire in the budget wars that have debilitated Washington since 2011.
articles.abstract: The deal, while modest in scope, amounts to a cease-fire in the budget wars that have debilitated Washington since 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House and Senate budget negotiators reached agreement Tuesday on a budget deal that would raise military and domestic spending over the next two years, shifting the pain of across-the-board cuts to other programs over the coming decade and raising fees on airline tickets to pay for airport security.

articles.headline: Dwindling Tools to Raise Wages
articles.snippet: The United States might not even need a minimum wage if it had some of the institutions that other advanced nations use to put a floor on workers’ living standards. But it doesn’t.
articles.abstract: The United States might not even need a minimum wage if it had some of the institutions that other advanced nations use to put a floor on workers’ living standards. But it doesn’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Kennedy once called the minimum wage “one of the best” tools for fighting poverty.

articles.headline: Study Finds Federal Contracts Given to Flagrant Violators of Labor Laws
articles.snippet: A Senate committee report urges the government to pay closer attention to safety and wage violations when awarding federal contracts.
articles.abstract: A Senate committee report urges the government to pay closer attention to safety and wage violations when awarding federal contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new congressional report criticizes the federal government for awarding tens of billions of dollars in contracts to companies even though they were found to have violated safety and wage laws and paid millions in penalties. Issued on behalf of the Democratic senators on the Health, Education, Labor and Pension Committee, the report cited examples over the past six years.

articles.headline: ‘Long and Arduous Process’ to Ban a Single Wall Street Activity
articles.snippet: The Volcker Rule’s chief intention is to prohibit regulated banks from using customer money to trade for their own gain, but it may have many potential gray areas.
articles.abstract: The Volcker Rule’s chief intention is to prohibit regulated banks from using customer money to trade for their own gain, but it may have many potential gray areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 6 feet 7 inches, Paul A. Volcker struck an imposing figure as chairman of the Federal Reserve during the economically turbulent 1980s.

articles.headline: After Setbacks, Online Courses Are Rethought
articles.snippet: Large-scale online courses, hailed as a way to democratize higher education, have so far been plagued by very high attrition rates.
articles.abstract: Large-scale online courses, hailed as a way to democratize higher education, have so far been plagued by very high attrition rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years after a Stanford professor drew 160,000 students from around the globe to a free online course on artificial intelligence, starting what was widely viewed as a revolution in higher education, early results for such large-scale courses are disappointing, forcing a rethinking of how college instruction can best use the Internet.

articles.headline: New Leadership for Lululemon in Management Shake-Up
articles.snippet: Lululemon announced on Tuesday that its founder, Dennis J. Wilson, would step down from his position as chairman of the board of directors, although he remains on the board.
articles.abstract: Lululemon announced on Tuesday that its founder, Dennis J. Wilson, would step down from his position as chairman of the board of directors, although he remains on the board.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perhaps going on television and suggesting that women with large thighs were not the ideal customer — at least when it comes to yoga pants — would never be considered advisable for the top executive of an athletic wear company.

articles.headline: Lebanon Worries That Housing Will Make Syrian Refugees Stay
articles.snippet: The experience of sheltering Palestinian refugees has made the Lebanese government wary of any housing for those fleeing Syria’s war that seems too permanent.
articles.abstract: The experience of sheltering Palestinian refugees has made the Lebanese government wary of any housing for those fleeing Syria’s war that seems too permanent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WADI KHALED, Lebanon — The modest shelter housing some Syrian refugees here, a few hundred yards south of the border with Syria, hardly looks objectionable. Made of plywood walls on a concrete foundation of some 250 square feet, with one door, two windows and a corrugated zinc roof, the squat structure is called a “box shelter.”

articles.headline: A Long Wait for a Last Moment With Mandela
articles.snippet: South Africans came by the thousands to pay their final respects to the most beloved of a generation of leaders who liberated their country from apartheid.
articles.abstract: South Africans came by the thousands to pay their final respects to the most beloved of a generation of leaders who liberated their country from apartheid.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — Patience Mashele put on her black, gold and green shirt, hat and skirt and left her house before dawn. She did not want to be late. It was time to say goodbye.
articles.byline: By Lydia Polgreen, Nicholas Kulish and Alan Cowell

articles.headline: Hardships Linger for a Mending Ireland
articles.snippet: A program of austerity, hailed as a successful recovery tool, has left many desperately struggling to survive.
articles.abstract: A program of austerity, hailed as a successful recovery tool, has left many desperately struggling to survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — On the rare days when John Donovan visits downtown Dublin, there is a buzz in the air: Streets bustle with pedestrians. “Sold” signs festoon Georgian brick buildings that had languished on the market for years. At Silicon Docks, a hub where Google, Facebook and other tech companies are clustered, crowds of taxis line up for easy fares.
